instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01814: What is 820-01814? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .
definitions.PP1V8_SSD0: What is PP1V8_SSD0? PP1V8_SSD0 is a power rail responsible for powering the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on newer Macbook Pros.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 not coming up
threads.message:
the system came initially with a nand short
On <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>, I cleared the short and restore with configurator2. It worked and sent out for deliver. After a week it was returned dead and I discovered another short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD0_SNS</SIGNAL>, I cleared it. Configurator2 successfully restored it ( the padlock logo came on the other laptop but the system in question has no display nothing. Still dead. Pls what to do

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 not coming up
threads.message:
Do you get SSD voltages now?
Also check G3S voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 not coming up
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD0</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> is also present
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> is present
I also noticed <SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> is 0.55V and it's suppose to be more than that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 not coming up
threads.message: Was the board affected by liquid spill?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 not coming up
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 not coming up
threads.message:
Do you get voltage on other big coils?
Check CPU core too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 not coming up
threads.message:
checked <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7220</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7230</CHIP> they all had there <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> voltages and <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> voltages, <SIGNAL>CPUCORE_PWM1</SIGNAL> was 0.2V and <SIGNAL>CPUCORE_FCCM</SIGNAL> was 2.3V.
there were no voltages on the big coils and the cpu core too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 not coming up
threads.message:
CPU core is the last voltage to appear.
Didn't find other coils to check?
Like PCH, RAM, etc...
